title: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
Hello... I'm back...

If you don't remember me, I'm najawa. I've just awoken from medically induced acoma, and have been given leave by my master, Mortimer McMire, to wreck havok on followers of the keenish cult.
I was suprised, when I woke up, that I am 15 years old, and a bit more mature...
Being idle for so long has sapped my ability to bug you guys... so without further ado:

Which came first: SGA, or English?

Was English first invented by the aliens, encoded into SGA, and then our ancestors made it "their own" implimenting the use of the Arabic Alphabet "A, B, C" and improving punctuation through the years?

Why is it that SGA is directly parallel with english? Why doesn't the sign over the rayguns translate into French or Greek? Why English? Is English the mother language we inherited from the aliens?

Seriously... why?!Tough Guys Wear Pink!!!
[img]http://i15.photobucket.com/albums/a371/najawa/Modding/tough_guys_wear_pink.jpg[/img]
[url=http://kevan.org/brain.cgi?Najawa]Click Here!!! Please!!![/url]
-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
Because it's the easy way to make up a new language, especially in fiction. I mean, even Google's Klingon languages uses the alphabet! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Welcome back btw. I know your nickname... That's all though. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-embarrassed.gif[/img] ____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
The Standard Galactic Alphabet has not been around long. It has existed for barely a few years.

Before SGA, many people spoke omnispeak; an oral language without any written form, it consists of a mere few hundred words and phrases, and is easily learned, being designed specifically to allow disparate species to communicate important things, like the fact that their ship was on fire.

Things changed not more than four years ago, when a new and powerful empire began to rise, capturing many worlds and enslaving their inhabitants. While speaking omnispeak, they also spoke and wrote a new language, known to them as 'Sezzleck Galaxie Alfbezz' or SGA. This was a language very different from what they had spoken previously, written in 26 symbols, without punctuation. It also had a strange resemblance to a language spoken and written in some continents on the planet Sol III (Known by its inhabitants as 'Earth')

As the Shikadi empire grew in power and influence, the SGA began to appear galaxy wide, though often not without a fight. Oddly, the Vorticons accepted this language remarkably fast and were all speaking it within six months as 'the will of the Grand Intellect.' With such support, the language was soon understood by almost everyone in the galaxy, though its origins remain unknown...
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
It's fun to come up with rational ideas about the reasons behind the canon facts in the Keen Universe. The way I see it, there are two possibilites:

-Najawa's idea, namely that aliens somehow planeted their language (English) long ago (I never thought of that).
-my idea, which is that Mortimer was the one who invented it after going to live with the Vorticons (which is how he learned advanced science and later got in control of them and in possession of advanced equipment to escape and become independant); the idea of a standard alphabet had been around for a while, and Mortimer was greatly in favor of it. Several character scripts were voted upon, and Mort's won. He decided to use English vocabulary to spare others the work of coming up with new words (though not always using the same spelling, since that is very unstandardazied in English). The SGA was only needed for important, priority information, such as exit and danger signs, in order that everyone could read and understand such things without having to learn a full language from another world, which was frequently very difficult. It would have no grammar beyond nouns, subject's, objects, and verbs, (simple to learn) because it was only used for labling things and wouldn't need complicated cases for personal pronouns and whatnot. Oh and an SGA hadn't been implemented yet because beings visiting other beings' homeplanets was not widespread until around the time Mortimer came to the Vorticons.

I hope that's all feasible; if you want a real challange, try explaining the "this is neat" signs lol, or the candy everywhere, or the candy in the shape of SGA letters. NO, NO, how about Keen standing in the clouds (Keen 3)! lol.
"Out of curiosity, what is that score in the Earth measurement system?"
"...That would be three hundred fifteen."
"Three hundred fifteen... This person must be the most intelligent being throughout the entire Universe."

title: Re: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]how about Keen standing in the clouds (Keen 3)! lol.[hr][/quote]

hmm. maybe the vorticons had platforms that they use to acess their higher security areas, but whenever someone of a high risk (ie keen) enters, vorticon cities produce large amounts of sticky fog. the fog will only fuse with materials found in the platforms, so stuff like buildings candy etc are unaffected.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Now all that remains is to explain why there are cannons in the Keen universe...[hr][/quote]

those aren't cannons, they are mini nuclear reactors. they regularly expel relatively harmless nuclear waste; yorps gargs and robots are unaffected by it; they have built up an immunity/were constructed to become immune to it. This means that only keen is affected by the waste, immobilising him; however due to the short half-life of the materials involved, the materials spontaneously combust after a short period of time, leaving keen free to move around again.

[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-lol.gif[/img]

---Freeyorp

title: Re: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
Okay, new question, though not off topic (at least as off topic as some of you have been)


Who wrote those signs? The Vorticons didn't; they might write "Raygun..." but not "Behold the Holy Pogo Stick."

The guard bots don't have hands, the butler bots are too short with too shorts arms, and they only can jump a pixle. Butler bots are also robots, and thus too impure to be allowed in such a shrine. Only one of the very holiest gargs is in there, but he is not allowed to see it even. He's stuck above it with only a little Teddy Bear Idol. If he tries to leave, he would fall into the blazing fire and incense below.

Who is left to paint these signs?

Maybe... the pogo did it!
Maybe Toy Story got it right!
Maybe the Martians have the true faith!
Maybe, the Martians saw the pogo come to life, and the pogo is an egoist...
Maybe the rayguns came to life

Maybe the candy is some eastern religion, and keen is collecting meditation candy bars that are floating in deep meditation!!!

Maybe, we're just not supposed to ask these kind of questions!!!
Maybe, we're too smart!!!

I wonder if ID software considers us dangerous: We're totally wrecking the validity of this game. We've proved it fiction over and over...

Or... we've proved something much deeper (and controversial)


----------------------------------------
I had so much fun writing that...

-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: Which came first: SGA, or English (I'm Back!)
content:
Nah, They must have arms and hands and opposible thumbs to do stuff, such as use a martian ray gun (canon element), not to mention build things and just be an intelligent creature in the first place. They must be able to retract into their bodies, like some other creatures on Earth can do (I think).

Wasn't there a drawing by one of the producers somewhere showing a Garg with squigly arms flailing at Keen? They looked like seaweed. I think the picture came with the ID anthology or something--some kind of collector's item. I know I saw it around here and the post said something like that. Not that it's necessarily canon, but I still think the best ex[planation is that they have arms, even if they never tried to grab or shoot keen lol."Out of curiosity, what is that score in the Earth measurement system?"
"...That would be three hundred fifteen."
"Three hundred fifteen... This person must be the most intelligent being throughout the entire Universe."

Well, the problem there is you're thinking too humanly; there is no law saying inteligent species must have opposable thumbs; dolphins are doing well, even just with flippers. (And some seals even use tools.) Octupi can do puzzles and unscrew jars with their tentacles, and rats can even run a claculator with their noses. I'm sticking with the prehenitisle eyestlk theory.
